content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Lyndon Baines Johnson's significant achievements in civil rights, education, and economic opportunity, including the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the Social Security Amendments Act of 1965, have had a lasting impact on American society. Medicare, along with Social Security, reduced elderly poverty from 28.5% in 1966 to 9.1% in 2012. President Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, religion, or national origin. He also signed the Higher Education Act in 1965, providing financial aid for students to make higher education more accessible. President Johnson signed the Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1965, abolishing the racially based quota system and prioritizing family reunification and skilled immigrants. Robert A. Caro praised Johnson as a champion of the poor and underprivileged, emphasizing his contributions to justice and mercy in American governance. The Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a posthumous gold medal to be awarded to Lyndon Baines Johnson for his contributions to the nation, including key legislative acts like the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Following the award of the gold medal to Lyndon Baines Johnson, it will be given to the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum for display and research. Congress suggests that the museum should also make the medal available for display at other locations associated with Johnson. The Secretary is authorized to produce and sell bronze duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under specific codes.
